THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN
MADISON 6
SCHOOL OF JOURNALISM RECEIV ) December 12, 1961
NAEB HEADQUARTERS
Mr# William G# Harley
President, NAEB
Dupont Circle Office Bldg#
1346 Connecticut Ave., N. W#
Washington 6, D. C.
Dear Bill:
ITm sorry that I didn!t get my answer to your query via Sam Becker off in time
for inclusion in Sair^s recent communication# Since the response is not unani¬
mous, I think ITd better put in my two centsT worth even now#
On the whole, my position is most like that of Kumata. The points I*d like to
underscore are these:
1) There are numerous private groups anxious to serve broadcasters interested
in getting research data on their audiences. On the whole they can do the job
more cheaply and uniformly than we could do it under the aegis of the national
office#
2) Furthermore, they can meet the usual conditions more readily than we can-
client control over content of survey, client control of publication, etc.
3) Many of us cannot meet these conditions at all# The University of Wisconsin
does not permit the use of its name in connection with purely commercial research
when contol of content and publication is not in the hands of the researcher#
Ifm sure we are not alone in this.
4) It would be all but impossible to guarantee a user uniform quality under the
circumstance^ you describe. Such uniformity could probably not be enforced by
the proposal* office without making the proposal excessively unattractive.
5) Many of us are still interested in the dynamics of audiences in relation to
content. But the usual commercial survey rarely adds to our mite of knowledge.
And it is unfortunately true that routine audience surveys tend to justify the
broadcaster in not taking risks, not trying something new, not worrying about
grave local issues that nevertheless lack the drawing power of Lawrence Welk.
Does NAEB want to associate itself with such a business?
As usual, I*m hopeful for any way NAEB can help us get significant research done
on broadcasting. But this proposal as it stands does not appear to be the ave¬
nue we are seeking.
